College of Materials Science and Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 China Graphical abstract Resource utilization of waste deNOx catalysts has become a major demand. A new resource path for continuous-flow catalysis using the waste deNOx catalysts (V2O5-WO3/TiO2, CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and MnO2-CeO2/TiO2) as carriers was proposed. The waste deNOx catalysts supported NiO catalysts prepared by an in-situ preparation method were used to investigate continuous-flow nanocatalysis of p-nitrophenol reduction. The result showed that the MnO2-CeO2/TiO2 supported NiO (Ni/TMC) exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the catalytic reduction of p-nitrophenol (4-NP). The conversion of 4-NP (2.5 mM) reached nearly 100% at the injection speed of 1.5 mL·min−1. It maintained 100% conversion after 10 recycling time since waste deNOx catalysts could reduce aggregation for NiNPs. Furthermore, high oxygen vacancy, chemisorbed oxygen, and the strong interaction between Ni and waste deNOx catalyst resulted in a highly efficient, recoverable and cost-effective multifunctional reactor. All of these advantages present the opportunity to be implemented in the field of wastewater treatment and environmental toxicology. Keywords Waste deNOx catalysts Continuous-flow Harmless disposal Ni nanoparticle Resource utilization 1 Introduction Currently, the main technology to deal with NOx is selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) [1–3]. After commercial catalysts (V2O5/TiO2, CeO2/TiO2, and MnO2/TiO2) reach the end of its service life, they are discarded and a large amount of solid waste is generated [4]. Especially for V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, the water solubility and toxicity of V2O5 will cause serious pollution to the environment [5,6]. Therefore, it is necessary to make rational use of the waste deNOx catalyst. On the other hand, heterogeneous catalysis combined with the traditional batch reactor is an essential technology for the modern chemical industry [7]. However, many disadvantages exist in the traditional batch reactor, such as low efficiency, concentration gradients, poor heat transfer, etc. [8]. In contrast, the continuous-flow (CF) presents great superiority to researchers due to its high operability, ease of reaction control, automation, and the ability to scale up [9,10]. It exhibits higher efficiency, better quality, and greater sustainability in many fields, such as green synthesis [11], microfluidic [12], catalysis [13,14], etc. These advantages guarantee that the CF forms an excellent alternative technology to replace the traditional batch reactor [15–17]. Simply, the combination of CF with heterogeneous catalysis has many unparalleled advantages and is increasingly becoming a powerful tool in the modern chemical industry. The development of CF in heterogeneous catalysis possesses is of significant value economically and in the field of research. Nanomaterials have been extensively investigated due to the unique size, large surface-area-to-volume ratios, and shape effect [18–22]. Metal nanocatalyst, an important member of nanomaterials, has increasing applications in various fields [23–25]. For instance, the aqueous Au-Pd colloids are used to catalyze selective CH4 oxidation to CH3OH [26]; the Au25(SG)18 nanoclusters are used for photothermal therapy [27], and the nickel nanoparticles (NiNPs) loaded cellulose filter paper is used for the p-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction [28]. Among these applications, environmental catalysis, especially in the field of water treatment, has gained attention due to the increase of stringent environmental regulations. Currently, Au/TiO2 [29], Pt-Fe3O4@graphene [30], Pd-Cu/g-C3N4 [31] and many other metal nanocatalysts have been used for water treatment [32–37]. Presently, the technology combination of noble metal nanocatalysis with CF exhibits obvious advantages (high reaction efficiency and reproducibility) in the field of water treatment [38]. However, one current challenge in designing the metal catalyst (anchored within CF reactors) with improved catalytic efficiency and reusability synchronously. For example, for the 4-NP reduction, the Pd/UiO-66-NH2 film capillary microreactor can be reused readily but its maximum flow rate is just 60 μL·min−1 [39]. In another example, the Au nanoparticles (AuNPs) anchored paper reactor can exhibit high catalytic efficiency at a flow rate of 0.25 mL·min−1 but the cellulose of paper would be gradually destroyed in an alkaline environment [18]. With this in mind, intensive research of the catalyst is imperative for cost and high catalytic efficiency for metal nanocatalysis. As an active ingredient, nickel is the excellent electron-donor or acceptor resulting in the capacity to promote the catalytic reaction by the redox cycle process significantly. Therefore, Ni nanomaterial has a great advantage in the catalytic reaction [40]. The high cost is one of the hurdles for the commercialization of noble metals. Nickel has appeared like a considerable alternative. Therefore, the presence of NiNPs provides a possibility for increasing the catalytic efficiency and reusability simultaneously in the field of water treatment. Recently, various materials have been used for the carriers, such as graphene oxide [41], TiO2 [42], polymer [43] and cellulose [44]. As the carrier, the waste deNOx catalyst is calcined as a ceramic carrier. In other words, the coupling of NiNPs and waste deNOx catalysts can be used for continuous-flow catalysis in the field of water treatment. Under the guidance of such an idea, the waste deNOx catalysts (V2O5-WO3/TiO2, CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and MnO2-CeO2/TiO2) were fabricated as the continuous-flow reactor. The ceramic deNOx catalysts supported NiNPs exhibited excellent catalytic performance for 4-NP reduction. It solves three problems simultaneously: solid pollution of waste deNOx catalyst (especially the toxicity problem of V2O5); water pollution of dye and resource utilization of waste catalyst. In addition, our previous research work has successfully applied V2O5-based deNOx catalysts to the field of reforming hydrogen production [45]. Compared with previous study, this work not only realizes the application of waste V2O5-based deNOx catalysts in water treatment, but also covers the utilization of three major types of metal oxide deNOx catalysts. In other words, this work confirms the universality of the resource utilization of waste deNOx catalysts. At last, this idea can be applied to the treatment of all commercial deNOx catalysts and the other environmental catalysis in the field of water treatment. 2 Experiment Supporting Information (SI) provided information about materials, chemicals, catalyst preparation, catalytic activity measurement, and characterization. From Fig. 1 , V2O5-WO3/TiO2, CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and MnO2-CeO2/TiO2 were calcined to ceramics and were designated as TVW, TCW, and TMC, respectively. Then NiNPs were self-assembly in the carrier so that Ni-based catalysts (denoted as Ni/TVW, Ni/TCW and Ni/TMC, respectively) were obtained. The CF nanocatalysis was conducted by the Ni/TCW, Ni/TMC and Ni/TVW reactors. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 2 (a) showed the ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) absorption spectra of the 4-NP solution with NaBH4 before and after feeding into the CF reactor. The characteristic peak intensity at 400 nm decreased and that at 300 nm increased after the reactor. Fig. 1S showed the peak position shifted from 315 nm to 400 nm when NaBH4 was added into the 4-NP solution. It was determined from the literature that the peak at 400 nm represented the 4-NP and the peak at about 300 nm represented p-aminophenol (4-AP) [46]. The relationship between 4-NP conversion and concentration was obtained and shown in Fig. 2(b). All catalytic efficiencies of Ni-based reactors could reach 100% at 1.5 mL·min−1 when 4-NP concentration was lower than 2 mM. The catalytic efficiency decreased with the increase of 4-NP concentration. When 4-NP concentration increased and the injection speed remained 1.5 mL·min−1, still only a part of 4-NP reacted with the catalyst, so some 4-NP molecules could not participate in the reaction, resulting in decreased activity. For TVW, TMC, and TCW, catalytic efficiency was at a low level at the whole interval of 4-NP concentration. It suggested that waste deNOx catalyst was only suitable as a carrier for water treatment and the other catalysis [45]. When the 4-NP concentration was 5 mM, the difference among Ni/TVW, Ni/TMC, and Ni/TCW reactors was obvious and the optimum catalyst could be obtained. The Ni/TMC exhibited the best catalytic performance (87.25%) at 1.5 mL·min−1. The maximum conversion decreased as Ni/TMC > Ni/TVW > Ni/TCW > TMC > TCW > TVW. From Table 1S, the loading amount of Ni decreased as Ni/TMC > Ni/TVW > Ni/TCW. The 4-NP conversion was basically positively correlated with specific surface area and the loading amount of Ni. The main reason for the highest conversion of Ni/TMC may be due to the loading content and the chemical state of NiNPs. It was also noted that the value of total organic carbon (TOC) had no great change before and after the reaction (Fig. 2S). Meaning, the 4-NP had been completely transformed to 4-AP with was no other by-product. The reusability of Ni/TMC was investigated (Fig. 3 ). The catalytic efficiencies of 4-NP reduction had no great change after 10 recycling times. Furthermore, the conversion rates of Ni/TMC could reach 99.5% (2.5 mM 4-NP) at the tenth recycling time. The efficiency loss was less than 1%. According to Table 1S, the loading amount of Ni just decreased 0.005%. In other words, the loading amount of Ni did not change obviously between before and after use for ten times. Compared with other catalysts, such as Cu2O@h-BN (50% activity loss after 4 recycling times) [47], Ni NPs in hydrogel network (25% activity loss after 5 recycling times) [48] and Ag/CH-FP (10% activity loss after 4 recycling times) [49], Ni/TMC exhibited a significantly better reusability. It was probably because the waste deNOx catalyst carrier reduced the leaching and aggregation for NiNPs. In other words, Ni/TMC had excellent reusability, which could be applied to the practical application. 3.2 Physical properties Fig. 4 showed SEM micrographs of the outside surface of different catalysts. For TVW and TCW, the particles were sintered into the smooth submicron sponge and there were distinct small pores between the sponges. The diameter of the sponge was mainly 0.25–1.5 μm. Opposite of this, the shape was between the particle and sponge for TMC and the surface was a bit rough. It indicated that waste deNOx catalyst has formed ceramics. In practical tests, the structure of catalysts could keep unchanged in water without collapsing, which verified that this degree of ceramization met the demand. As shown in Fig. 4(b), (d) and (f), there were three different states for NiNPs. There was no agglomeration for NiNPs on the TCW surface and the diameter of NiNPs was relatively small, which was due to the smooth surface of TCW and the large channels. A small part of NiNPs was agglomerated on the TVW surface because the channel diameter became smaller. When the TMC surface was rough, a large amount of NiNPs was agglomerated on the surface. It was because NiNPs was more likely to agglomerate and adhere to rough surfaces. Furthermore, the element distribution of TVW, Ni/TVW, TMC, Ni/TMC TCW and Ni/TCW was obtained by element mapping (Fig. 3S to Fig. 8S). It could be seen that all the elements were evenly distributed in the catalyst. Compare with the Ni element mapping of three catalysts, it also could be found that the loading amount of NiNPs decreased as Ni/TMC > Ni/TVW > Ni/TCW. Fig. 5 (a) showed the X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra of different catalysts. All the reflections corresponded to the rutile TiO2 (PDF-ICDD 76-326), SiO (PDF-ICDD 30-1127), Ni (PDF-ICDD 3-1043), CeO2 (PDF 65-5923), SrTiO3 (PDF-ICDD 1-1018) and MnO2 (PDF-ICDD 2-567). For TVW and Ni/TVW, the main peaks were attributed to rutile TiO2, and there was no diffraction peak for V, W or Al species. Compared to element mapping results, the loading amount of these species was relatively low and they had a good dispersion in the TVW and Ni/TVW samples. For TMC and Ni/TMC, the presence of new peaks attributed to SiO and SrTiO3 indicated it was difficult for Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 to react at high temperature to form ceramic phase. Therefore, the surface of particles for TMC was rough. For TCW and Ni/TCW, the main crystal phases were CeO2 and rutile TiO2. The peak at 26° belongs to MnO2, and the intensity increased significantly after the addition of Ni, which may be due to the growth of the crystal size during the calcination. Besides, the intensity of peaks attributed to NiO was much low because of the low loading amount. To further research the physical properties of Ni-based catalysts, the outside surface of all samples were characterized by the Raman spectra. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the three peaks located at 245, 442 and 602 cm−1 were assigned to rutile TiO2 [50]. The weak peak in 160 cm−1 was attributed to anatase TiO2 [51]. However, compared to rutile, the intensity was very low, which indicated that the amount of anatase TiO2 was much lower than that of rutile TiO2. It was consistent with the XRD result because there was no obvious peak corresponding to anatase TiO2. Besides, the Raman spectra demonstrated that Ni-based catalysts showed a negative shift in comparison with ceramic carriers. The shift corresponded to an increase in the number of surface oxygen species [52]. Table 1 and Fig. 9S exhibited the detail information about the pore and the specific surface area. From Fig. 9S, it was found that the average pore diameter of TCW and TVW increased with the addition of Ni, and the amount of pore (6–12 nm) increased obviously, indicating that the loading of Ni did not block the original pores of the catalyst. Opposite to this, the pore distribution (3–5 nm) of TMC increased. Combined with the results of SEM images, it was speculated that the agglomerated NiNPs blocked the part pores of the catalyst. Therefore, the surface area and Pore volume increased for TCW to Ni/TCW and TVW to Ni/TVW, but decreased for TMC to Ni/TMC. However, the surface area of Ni/TMC was still the largest than the other two catalysts. Furthermore, the specific surface area of these catalysts was much smaller than that of common catalysts [53–55]. It verified that the waste deNOx catalysts have been sintered to ceramic powder. In addition to Ni/TVW catalyst, the specific surface area and catalytic efficiency of other catalysts were positively correlated. It was because the specific surface area and the micron channel directly determined the reaction time and reaction area of NiNPs and reactants. On the other hand, the more complete the sintering of ceramic particles, the more difficult it was to dissolve the active components of waste deNOx catalyst in the water. In other words, the sintering temperature of waste deNOx catalyst was an important factor in further study. 3.3 Surface active species Fig. 6 and Fig. 10S showed the Ti 2p, O 1s, Ni 2p, Ce 3d, W 4f, Mn 2p and V 2p high-resolution scans spectra of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and Table 2 showed the atomic distribution. From Fig. 6(a), Ti 2p was divided into Ti3+ and Ti4+ and the Ni modification improved the amount of Ti3+. Correspondingly, the interaction between Ni and TiO2 caused the generation of oxygen vacancies. According to our previous study, the concentrations of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst were related to that of Ti3+ because the transition from Ti4+ to Ti3+ produced oxygen vacancies [56–58]. Therefore, the Ti3+ amount increased obviously when Ni was loaded. From Fig. 6(b), there were two contributions for O 1s: chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) and lattice oxygen (Oβ). For TMC and Ni/TMC catalysts, a new peak corresponded to surface oxygen by hydroxyl species (Oγ) appeared [59]. Surface chemisorbed oxygen or hydroxyl species could promote the catalytic reaction obviously [60]. Therefore, the addition of Ni improved the amount of Oα+ Oγ, which helped improve the catalytic performance. Meanwhile, both the O 1s and Ti 2p peaks showed a shift toward the lower binding energy with the addition of Ni, indicating there were strong interactions among Ni, O, and Ti. This strong interaction could accelerate the transmission of electrons so that the ceramic carriers participate in the reaction better. Fig. 6(c) exhibited the representative Ni 2p spectra of Ni/TCW, Ni/TMC, and Ni/TVW. There were two contributions of Ni2+ and satellite for Ni 2p. The weak peak located at 852.2 eV was metallic Ni (Ni0). The additional peaks located at 882.2 eV for Ni/TCW and Ni/TMC catalysts were attributed to Ce 3d because the part of peaks of Ce 3d and Ni 2p were overlapping. The presence of Ni2+ was likely to be NiO/hydroxide during catalyst processing when exposed to air. In addition, although the Ni0 was oxidized to Ni2+, all the catalysts still exhibited excellent catalytic performance like the fresh catalysts. Fig. 6(d) exhibited the Ce 3d XPS spectra of TCW, TMC, Ni/TCW and Ni/TMC catalysts. There were two contributions of Ce3+ and Ce4+ for Ce 3d [61]. The intensity of Ce 3d peaks over TCW or TMC was higher than that over Ni/TCW or Ni/TMC. The Ce3+ had excellent redox properties and it would consume NaBH4 quickly so that the reducing agent adsorbed on Ni surface reduced. In other words, the catalyst exhibited more excellent catalytic performance when the Ce3+ atomic ratio decreased. The CeO2 was more suitable as a cocatalyst than an active component. 4 Conclusions In this work, a feasible approach to synthesize waste deNOx ceramic catalyst supported Ni was developed. The Ni/TCW, Ni/TMC and Ni/TVW catalysts were used firstly for continuous-flow catalysis. While we have proven, the waste deNOx ceramic catalyst supported Ni nanoparticle possessed high catalytic activity for 4-NP reduction. All of these advantages helped the waste deNOx ceramic carrier be used for practical application. coredata.dc:description: Resource utilization of waste deNOx catalysts has become a major demand. A new resource path for continuous-flow catalysis using the waste deNOx catalysts (V2O5-WO3/TiO2, CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and MnO2-CeO2/TiO2) as carriers was proposed. The waste deNOx catalysts supported NiO catalysts prepared by an in-situ preparation method were used to investigate continuous-flow nanocatalysis of p-nitrophenol reduction. The result showed that the MnO2-CeO2/TiO2 supported NiO (Ni/TMC) exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the catalytic reduction of p-nitrophenol (4-NP). The conversion of 4-NP (2.5 mM) reached nearly 100% at the injection speed of 1.5 mL·min−1. It maintained 100% conversion after 10 recycling time since waste deNOx catalysts could reduce aggregation for NiNPs. Furthermore, high oxygen vacancy, chemisorbed oxygen, and the strong interaction between Ni and waste deNOx catalyst resulted in a highly efficient, recoverable and cost-effective multifunctional reactor. All of these advantages present the opportunity to be implemented in the field of wastewater treatment and environmental toxicology.
coredata.dc:title: Resource utilization of waste deNOx catalyst for continuous-flow catalysis by supported metal reactors
